body:
Thanks @fin.

We've run into that a couple times. That's why we include our own implementation of Quicksort in the `technology.tabula.Quicksort` class. Can you try replacing the `Collections.sort` call in `Cell.java` with our Quicksort implementation? Otherwise, if you can provide us with a PDF that triggers the bug, I'll implement a fix.
Actually, all the `Collections.sort` calls should be replaced with [`Utils.sort`](https://github.com/tabulapdf/tabula-java/blob/master/src/main/java/technology/tabula/Utils.java#L121)

issue.title: replace Collections.sort with tabula.Utils.sort where possible
issue.body:
fixes #116 in the case I encountered in the wild

note that there are still calls to Collections.sort present, where the comparator function is given in the call itself. Ideally, Utils.sort should gain a way to receive a Comparator as well, but that's a bit over my paygrade, java-skills-wise.

body: in addition to that pull request, I'm happy to send you the pdf causing the exception, but I'd prefer for it not to be published.

I was trying to work on this one, but the problem seem to be in the logic rather than in the code and I don't know the codebase at all. Long story short, the issue is that compareTo implementations must be transitive (it should make sense, but see https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/Comparable.html#compareTo(T) if needed). The current implementation, which can be paraphrased as > If the two boxes overlap by at least .4, order left-to-right, > otherwise order top-to-bottom. This is transitive for the "normal" case: but fails when the boxes are like: because A and C do not overlap enough vertically and so C is considered to come after B but before A. Not 100% I've been able to explain myself... here are two test methods [tests.java.txt](https://github.com/tabulapdf/tabula-java/files/1261660/tests.java.txt) (add them into`TestRectangle`). I'd very gladly fix this thing myself, but I'm not sure what the ordering of rectangles should be... maybe different criteria will be needed in different situations? For reference, the fact that `Rectangle` implements `Comparable` is used in: - `Cell.getText(boolean useLineReturns)` - `RectangleSpatialIndex.contains(Rectangle r)` - `RectangleSpatialIndex.intersects(Rectangle r)` - `SpreadsheetDetectionAlgorithm.detect(Page page)` - `SpreadsheetExtractionAlgorithm.findSpreadsheetsFromCells(List cells)` - `SpreadsheetExtractionAlgorithm.extract(Page page, List rulings)`

Hi @giorgiga,

Thanks for taking a look at this. Transitiveness while sorting 2D elements lexicographically is, probably, impossible to achieve. That's why PDFBox and Tabula include the notion of 'tolerance' when comparing elements.

So far, we haven't run in to breaking cases with the code that we have now. In any case, there are long discussions about a related problem in PDFBox's issue tracker: [PDFBOX-1512](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PDFBOX-1512) and [PDFBOX-2966](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PDFBOX-2996)

> Transitivity of comparison operators is not a matter of complying to Comparator/Comparable contracts or some other java technicality... comparison operators must be transitive because otherwise there is no ordering (in the math sense) to begin with.

Yes, but as I understand the issue, there are multiple possible "orderings" in a 2D plane, so transitivity is difficult to define properly, right?

The point of using an ordering of 2d rectangles is sorting glyphs in "reading" (RTL or LTR) order. See PDFBox's [`PDFTextStripper`](https://github.com/apache/pdfbox/blob/bc8deb87969b2a9f5aedadc7dcaa54322fab97cb/pdfbox/src/main/java/org/apache/pdfbox/text/PDFTextStripper.java#L491-L501) and [`TextPositionComparator`](https://github.com/apache/pdfbox/blob/bc8deb87969b2a9f5aedadc7dcaa54322fab97cb/pdfbox/src/main/java/org/apache/pdfbox/text/TextPositionComparator.java)

Hi @giorgiga,

> Maybe in some cases the call to sort() can be replaced with things that aren't a sorting algorithm... one would need to know the intentions behind the various calls to sort() in order to say.

Yes, that sounds about right. To avoid misinterpretations and misuses of sorting algorithms, we should use something different than the `Comparable` interface.

BTW, I've been looking at your fork, and I really like the refactors that you've made. Are you interested in sending us a pull-request?

issue.title: General cleanup and refactoring
issue.body:
Done some work towards removing the use of sorting when not 100% appropriate (see #116).

Also, removed unnecessary generic type parameters (eg: `List<X> = new ArrayList<X>()`) and done some general housekeeping.

I've deprecated a few methods in Page that I'm not actually sure aren't used by dependants (ie: the tabula app).

Changes should be source-compatible with the original version (unless I messed up) - not binary compatible I fear.

body: Pull request: #187 (appveyor fails, but so does it in master)

Thanks @giorgiga,

Will review and merge within the next few days.
